There wasn't much direction beyond that, so we immediately made a beeline to the Market Table (photo: http://bit.ly/1Wg3uwV). It was an expansive buffet-style table full of salads and cold side dishes that reminded me of that scene in "Fargo" when Marge and Norm piled up on chicken fricassee. To say that was a meal in itself would be redundant since they offer a Market Table-only dining option for $28.95.

I always forget to graze less at the Market Table (photo: http://bit.ly/1XeQOpK) because it only means I can eat less of the meat to come, at least in theory. It didn't take long after we sat down that the meat started to pass by us. Dare we turn our cards over. Yes, yes we did, and the gluttony didn't stop. We tried at least three of the six steak options: Picanha (the prime part of the Top Sirloin; Filet Mignon; and Costela (Beef Ribs) (photo: http://bit.ly/1rAF6tv). All were succulent and tasty. We were less enamored with the Lombo (Pork Loin) and Frango (Chicken Legs) which we found overcooked (photo: http://bit.ly/1WRKsMz). Meanwhile, the server left us plates of Grilled Polenta and heavily creamed Garlic Mashed Potatoes (photo: http://bit.ly/1WhrAYN).

Needless to say, we were about to reach capacity when I weakened and ordered dessert, the $10.50 South American Flan, which was decent enough though quite refrigerated in temperature (photo: http://bit.ly/1T4NEC0). The effusive manager came by to see how we were doing, and I have to say that was a nice touch in an otherwise impersonal calorific extravaganza. On the way out, I took a quick look at the series of ovens where the meat was prepared, and it was an impressive operation since they apparently don't serve meat that's been out of the ovens for more than two minutes (photo: http://bit.ly/1Wg3pJB). Leftovers must be amazing for the staff at the end of the night.

FOOD - 4 stars...impressive Market Table choices, steak skewers are the best, the rest somewhat skippable
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...quite a sleek operation for such a big space
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...a bit automatic but then again, those skewers look pretty unwieldy
TOTAL - 4 stars...pricey but if you're a hungry carnivore, it might be worth a splurge
author: Ed U.

description:
I took my boyfriend here for his birthday recently and I regret it. We waited over 25 minutes to be sat when we had a reservation, which was fine. We weren't in a rush although it would've been nice to be sat at the time I called for. Our real problem was with the service. Our waitress kept forgetting about us from the get-go. I had plenty of food on my plate before my cocktail came which took almost half an hour. She said she would bring us a free dessert because of the wait. It would've been free anyways since we were celebrating a birthday but she didn't know. Anyways, we had asked for cheese bread, which never came. She checked on us once throughout the hour and a half we were there. She was super attentive to all the older people she was waiting on. There was one time where I wanted another cocktail and I even tried to get her attention by waving at her (which I hate to do) and she looked straight at me and looked away. Another really nice lady started to help us instead, I liked her a lot better but we were still being forgotten. I asked my boyfriend if there was ANYTHING we had said or did to offend this girl in ANY way and we couldn't think of anything! I understand it might be because we're younger and maybe they thought we wouldn't tip good. Me and my boyfriend both work in restaurants as a manager and a server, so we know how to tip and we would NEVER treat anyone like this. No matter the age. When I asked the second lady for another drink, she told our original waitress and I saw her laugh and walk away from her. Well lady, you missed out on a great tip!! I couldn't believe I spent almost $200 on this place. I ended up apologizing to my boyfriend for taking him there for his birthday and promised him we would never come back. 

P.S.-If you get the woman with a tattoo on her neck, ask for another waitress!!
author: Megan B.

description: Good Service, Great Food. I love the salad bar and the endless cuts of meat that come to your table until you are stuffed! Took my friend for the first time and he is a heavy meat eater. He came out super satisfied! Tip to first timers...take small cuts first and see which ones you like the most...save your tummy for 2nds of your favs!
author: Christopher S.

description: BEST steak that I've ever had. Went here last weekend. They have various kind of meat, my favorite will be the lamb. They have lamp steak, chops, leg. All of them are really tasty, besides that I had rib eye, strong taste of beef, and it was very nice either. The filet mignons was so so, had a lack of taste. Service could be better since it's hard to reach a waiter. Overall it was nice and the price is fair.
author: Calvin H.

description:
Have eaten here 3x in the past year, the most recent October 1, Sunday night 6:00pm.   Party of 6.    Food - the meat is excellent; you cannot deny it, and we enjoy it.     

Why 3 stars tonight?    First being the bar and kitchen.   Our first round of drinks arrived quickly, maybe 10 minutes; I applaud you.    Second round of drinks took 25 minutes; way too long.        

Why 3 stars tonight?   Unlike previous visits, the Filet Mignon came thru only once, and the time he did bring Filet Mignon, he was almost out of it, we literally took the last small piece he had.   He said he would return shortly with more Filet, but never returned; some of us did not have the chance to have any.  We had to request from our server the Filet Mignon to return, had to request a 2nd time from another wait-staff, and he finally came back.    I realize the Filet Mignon is probably a more expensive cut, but it seemed that this meat is purposely not brought out as frequently as other meat choices.   Understandable, but really, we are only getting one small "slice" per person, do you really think we are eating that much of your profits?

Why 3 stars tonight?   When it came to order desserts, it took over 30 minutes to get our desserts....  The waitress apologized, explained there was only ONE dessert chef working that night.      Unfortunately, we were celebrating my mom's 84th birthday.... she probably felt 85 years old by the time her dessert arrived.

Why 3 stars tonight?    You need more staff.    It was a Sunday night; it was day 1 of HUGE Oracle convention letting out.    You had to know it was going to be busy.      I hope you don't use that as your only excuse.

I will surely return, but I am hoping the manager realizes what was happening that night.
author: Edward H.

description: Nice cool classy place in the Lovely city of Frisco right next to the job so I had to try it. Really cool lunch special not bad on the pocket. I would definitely recommend others to come to at least give it a try.
author: Mychelle T.

description:
FOOD: fantastic.
SERVICE: disorganised 

My husband and I love this restaurant and have dinner there 5 or 6 times since moving into the neighbourhood. Food is always excellent. Service is hit or miss and last night it was a huge miss.

Our server never took a drink order, so we sat there with drink menus for quite some time until the manager came to take our order personally.
Typically, you receive a plate of sides at the start of your meal. When I flagged down our server to ask if we could order some, I was told sharply that "they come out when you turn your indicator to green". I've never even had to ask for sides before, they simply arrived, so this was news to me. He then asked "so do you want them now or..." and I said yes please . I thought to myself, why else would I be asking?

The sides then didn't arrive. Later in the meal, another server checked in on us and we advised no sides. She apologised. We then said don't worry about them as we were nearly finished our meal.
Of course, as we're getting ready to ask for a check (around 45mins after we sat down) our original server returns with a plate of sides. We said no thanks we're finishing up, and he shook his head and muttered something under his breath.

Staff overall looked confused and careless on this particular occasion. And our guy just had a bit of an attitude, which is why I'm writing this review. If he'd been good-natured or apologetic, I wouldn't have cared about the drinks or the sides. But he was impolite and it soured our night.
author: Peita D.

description: The restaurant is good and try the best to accommodate your needs. I am Brazilian and I think for those who like meat it is a wonderful place to be. The waiters were nice and friendly but the overall service quality is bad. For example I had gotten an email that indicated that there is a promotion valid until August 30 in which you pay for the meat service 39 dinner per person, so when we got our bill they charged us the full price which was 63 dollars. I complained and showed to the person that I wanted the price they stipulated on the email and she said that I should have warned them in advance that I knew about it. So folks be aware of what they are going to charge you ok? Very dissatisfied with the service. I am happy that o challenged them and you should do the same until August 30.
author: Iara C.

description:
Birthday dinner! 

My boyfriend took me to Fogo de Chao for my 28th birthday last week. He has Brazilian friends and they love the restaurant. Can't stop raving about it. Well, almost a year since I heard about it, he made a reservation for my birthday. 

When the host retrieved our reservations, she immediately wished me "Happy Birthday!" They sat us in a calmer section away from the crowds, but with a view of the meat kitchen. So cool! The meal was almost $60 per person, but essentially it's an all you can eat steakhouse, so it's worth it. 

The sides were also delicious. I loved the garlic mashed potatoes, polenta fries, plantains, and Brazilian cheese bread.

My favorite was the low sirloin that has salt crystals grilled onto its sides. The other meat dishes were great, too. Definitely don't leave without trying their house streak.

We also ordered a bottle of Alamos red wine ($48).

I also got a complimentary molten lava cake dessert for my birthday. Delicious! My boyfriend was trying really hard to suppress his sugar craving, but he had to have a couple bites (basically half of the cake). 

Fogo de Chao is a great place for a special occasion. Definitely a must try experience. 

Tip 1: If you sign up for their newsletter, they will give you a $15 discount on your first meal. 

Tip 2: They are also running a Valentine special. Eat on Valentines week, and receive a free meal card for your next visit. Great deal!
author: Joanna S.

description:
This place is similar to Espectsu in San Mateo or San Francisco. They serve Brazilian grilled meat in an all you can eat style. They are slightly more expensive than Espectsu.

As I arrived in the restaurant, I was greeted by the hostess and it took them about 10 minutes to seat us. It was a Saturday evening and I get that they had to arrange the tables first. We were seated and our server came by to say hello and asked us if we wanted any drinks. They have a salad bar for you to grab whatever you want and need. Service was fast as soon as we flip the cards to green, the meat was juicier and texture felt better than other places. I felt that their interior design/decoration and everything was more modern and nicer (because they are a relatively new restaurant) they also have a bar area if you don't have want to eat. 

I recommend coming here if you like Espectsu. It's worth a try!
author: Sammi L.

description:
You know that episode of I Love Lucy where she and Ethel frantically worked the chocolate assembly line but just couldn't keep up? 

Well, that's how I felt at Fogo. The meats just kept coming! And coming! And coming! It was my first time at a Brazilian BBQ place. I felt like I was in an eating contest and losing quickly. Ha.

A lean, fit guy sat at the table next to us, dining alone. He declared with a laugh when the hostess inquired whether it was his first time there: "Definitely not." I had nothing better to do after eating like a fiend for 15 minutes and then bursting at the seams, so I sat and watched him. His only loot from the salad bar was three slices of bacon. After that, nothing but medium rare beef. Smart move! 

I'd recommend the top sirloin and ribeye. Skip everything else if you have the discipline.

As for me...doubtful I'd go back. It's delicious, but I need help with portion control and I know it.
author: Kristen S.

description: The food was amazing but we reserved for a time and they gave us the table an hour later. The service was good I just wish they had better organization
author: Maria Y.

description: Only complaint was that our actual waiter was very inattentive to the table, but other people made up for his lack of attentiveness. Food was great but it is a bit pricey, $60 per person.
author: Emma J.

description:
I'll try to be as indifferent as I can as I love the Rodizio concept in general.. Overall it was good but I was slightly disappointed; not a terrible experience, but not the greatest either. So far I've also eaten at the Santana Row location, Downtown Chicago, and now, 3rd St SF. 

- Wait staff was attentive, but our waiter was not educated on menu. 
- Salad bar was fresh but not labeled for guests (hard to know what was what)
- Meats were cooked to preference but some (like the fillet mignon) lacked flavor
- Drinks were excellent (I ordered a caipirinha and it was mixed just right)
- The Brazilian cheese rolls (pao de queijo) were hot and fluffy

Overall it was a good experience; but a few tweaks will make it an excellent experience.
author: Brandon O.

description:
This place is located at a nice central location on the corner of a busy intersection downtown SF across from Yerba Buena and the W hotel. From the outside, it looks grand, but when you walk in, you can't help it but to be surprised with a narrow layout, very small bar, and an odd sitting area near the bar. They have an outdoors bar sitting area which seems to be nice but it is closed for now. So during the summer, that might become a nice after work cocktail place. 

I was a bit thrown off by the layout of the floor as the main salad bar is on the back of this L shaped restaurant so for those sitting by the front of the restaurant you have quite a walk to get their salad or sides. 

Salad Bar - disappointing. Very limited options, very small and not enticing. So vegetarians accompanying meatarians for dinner, eat before coming to dinner here. 

Service - EXCELLENT! Friendly, attentive, and efficient. I am impressed. Starting at the bar. I had a mango drink which was a tad too sweet. The bartender inquired about it and when I gave him feedback that the drink was sweet, he created a drink with fresh strawberries with the same base and it was delicious! I really appreciated his attitude of trying to make the customer happy. Eder and Thiago were our servers  and they were exceptional. 

APPETIZERS: the sliders were Ah-mazing. Sliders made out of cheese bread.?!! You can not go wrong with that! 

The MEAT - hit and miss. Some were incredibly delicious, some were tasteless. The variety was lacking and the same cuts would come around often. The better cuts were more of a rare occurrence but upon request, it would eventually come around. 

SIDE DISHES - if you are a serious meat eater, stick with light salad and eat your meat. The sides will quickly fill you up. Heavenly cheese bread (Pão de Queijo), fried banana, fried polenta ( I secretly wished they were fried yucca) and mashed potatoes. 

The DESSERT- oh my dear God. I am Brazilian, I go to Brazilian steakhouses often and always have papaya mousse and I can safely say, I have never tasted a better one. It was, oh so good. I shall say it tasted orgasmic! Highly encourage papaya mouse with cassis liquor. 

All in all, it was a pleasant experience especially because of the excellent service and their willingness to make us happy. Thank you Fogo. I shall be back!
author: Monique T.

description:
Just left fogo and I am impressed. 10 stars!!! At first, I didn't like where I was sitting, and talked to the manager, Mahelly, who took care of us. She was amazing and gave my boyfriend and me the best fogo experience. She went above and beyond to make sure that we didn't leave fogo on a bad note. Mahelly said she would make things better if we gave her the chance. She is a woman to her word. Great customer service! Mahelly checked on us consistently to make sure everything was great. In fact, Mahelly was the first person to greet us when we walked in. I will definitely come back again, and don't think any Fogo de Chau will reach the standards Mahelly set. 


The meat was delicious. Expect your eyes to roll back on the first bite. Great service, and the servers cut very healthy portions.
author: Jasmine O.

description:
What a disgrace!  This location ruined our Christmas dinner!  Being such fans of Fogo de Chao, we thought it'd be nice to dine at their SF location, since we're always dining at the LA location.  It's safe to say not all locations operate the same.  As soon as we entered and heard the hostess speak, I knew there'd be a problem at this location.  First of all, as a hostess, you should always make eye contact and smile.  Even if you're tired, pretend or, as the expression says, "fake it 'til you make it".  This hostess had such a dry attitude and act as if we were bothering her.  Without making any eye contact, she looked down at the computer screen and mumbled, "name?".  I started to say, "Webster", as in the dictionary, so she could use it to look up the word "courtesy".  Anyway, this dining experience was just starting, in all the bad directions.

We were seated in the middle of the restaurant, in a rather busy area, until we requested to be moved to another table.  This same hostess still hasn't smiled, so we'll just assume she had dental work the previous day and her facial muscles are still sore.  A server came to our table, and appeared to be jovial, but we didn't see him much thereafter.  We made our way to the serving stations but, to our surprise, there wasn't anyone at the meat carving station, and the tri-tip was left unattended for quite some time.  I went to get some of the sweet potato soufflé but the container was empty.  So, I asked one of the employees if they'll be bringing out a new container and he replied, "in about 20 minutes".  Immediately, I thought, we've never had to wait for any food at the LA location, as every food item is replaced almost immediately.  Anyway, we made our way back to our table to wait for the meat to arrive.  For whatever reason, some of these employees seem to rush to the table with the meat, causing the juice from the meat to spill onto the tablecloth.  Then, there were long gaps of time between receiving meat at our table.  After 20 minutes, I went to check on the sweet potato soufflé again, but was informed by the same employee, from 20 minutes prior, that it will be an additional 20 minutes.  At this point, I asked for a Manager and was informed there wasn't a Manager.  What the heck?!  I walked to the front of the restaurant and asked the aloof hostess for the General Manager.  She said she didn't see him but said she'll find him.  I asked for the name of the GM, and requested he, or she, be sent to our table.  Before going back to our table, I decided to stop and get rice but, much to my surprise, the rice container was empty, as well.  To our dismay, it was rather obvious that we'd have to find dinner elsewhere, which would be highly unlikely on a major holiday.  So, when Daniel, the GM, arrived to our table he was very kind and immediately apologized about the sweet potatoes.  Without delay, I informed him that there was much more of a problem than sweet potatoes.  Daniel apologized and ensured us that matters will get better and, unfortunately, they didn't.

All in all, we decided to leave this restaurant.  The staff did come to our table more after we talked with Daniel, but it was obvious that they were forced.  Daniel came back to the table to apologize again, and stated they've been open for only a year.  I'm sorry, but a year is more than enough time to have a well-trained staff for any given business.  I explained to Daniel how amazing and professional their LA location is, and that we frequent that location regularly.  As a courtesy, Daniel comped our meal and provided a gift card for "lunch only" at any of their locations.  That was a nice gesture, but doesn't erase the experience endured at this restaurant.   Hopefully, the GM will take the constructive criticism and apply it accordingly.
author: Tony Y. Jr. Y.

description:
Dinner review. Following topics as compared to other Brazilian steakhouses. 

Meat variety - Good
Meat quality - Decent
Problem #1 - Many of the meats were overcooked.
Problem #2 - Less desirable meats brought by constantly. Good meats rarely or never brought by.
Problem #3 - Express requests for meats are still not brought over until the 4th or 5th request.
Problem #4 - Refusal by servers to give specific cuts or portions. 

Overall, high expectations met with disappointment. "I think not."
author: Mark O.

description:
He's been wanting to come here since it first opened and he's been to Fogo in Atlanta several times but this was my first time.  I prepared myself by having a very light lunch of salad...nope, still wasn't prepared enough for Friday's dinner!

Full churrasco dinner (16 cuts of meat, market bar, soup, and condiments) = delicious. We tried 13 out of 16, and we had to flip the card several times and finally conceded to being way too full.  We tried top sirloin, bottom sirloin, NY strip steak, steak with bacon, ribeye, pork ribs, pork tenderloin, pork chop, pork sausage, chicken with bacon, chicken breast (per my request because I was tired of bacon), leg of lamb and lamb chops. All of the meats were perfectly cooked, full of flavor and moist. 

The market bar was excellent in quality and selection, and I absolutely loved the hearts of palm and marinated mushrooms. 

Side dishes: I enjoyed the polenta fries, while he enjoyed the mashed potatoes. But we both loved the caramelized bananas.  He $59.95/pp

Since it was his birthday, I ordered the molten lava chocolate cake, and a candle, and it was shockingly complimentary on the check! It was delicious, large enough to share for two people and served a la mode. 

Service = friendly.  

Prices = moderate. They will add a SFHCSD surcharge of 2% to the bill. Dinner for two came out to $116.10.  

This would be a fun place for a large group/special occasion.  Better save up pennies.
author: Fannie S.

description:
One of my favorite Brazilian restaurant . 
I checked their Beverly Hills location before and it was my first experience in SF location . It was smaller size but more modern look . Salad bar was great with high quality cheeses and cold cuts and lots . Food as always fantastic , service great , very friendly staff . 
If you like BBQ Highly recommended .
author: payam b.

description:
The service here was great and the ambience is nice , too , it's perfect for any sort of celebratory occasion ,
It was enjoyable experience !
author: Adna D.

description:
THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!! Truly a meat lovers paradise... and don't even get me started on their salad bar.

We had reservations so we were seated fairly quickly. It also got busy later on as I looked at their entrance so I recommend either making a reservation or coming early. They start you off with bread (which is a trap, it's super good but will fill you up, try to eat less of it!) All of their meats here are cooked perfectly and you can even choose what kind of cut you what and how you want it. My favorite has to be to lamb chops which were full of flavor and then the filet mignon and the top sirlion. 

What I also love about this place is their amazing salad bar. But be careful and don't get too full off the salad bar! You gotta save room for the meats. The salad bar included premium cheeses, smoked salmon, veggies, different types of salad and different types of salami.

Definitely a place to come for a celebration dinner/lunch or even a a special occasion. Highly recommended!
author: Sherry L.

description:
I'm giving up red meat for a little while and wanted to try Fogo de Chao before doing so. The roommate and I decided to come here for dinner on Monday, February 8th. I made a reservation for 6pm through OpenTable table the week prior.

Since we got there early, we hung out at the bar for a quick drink. They have happy hour in the bar area, Monday through Friday, 4:30pm-6:30pm. I got a glass of wine: Fogo de Chao, "Gran Reserva", Malbec - Mendoza, Argentina ($10). It was a generous pour. It's normally $16, so I saved $6 with their HH pricing. We didn't finish our drinks before 6pm, so we took them to our table. The roommate got The Macallan 18 yr ($34).

Finally, the all you can eat meat fest can begin! Dinner is $59.95 per person and also includes their salad bar, bread that resembled mini popovers, garlic mashed potatoes, polenta fries and fried bananas. Their mashed potatoes were pretty good. I only tried a few things from the salad bar: asparagus, mozzarella, mushrooms, roasted garlic and smoked salmon. The roommate got a huge mixed greens salad with some cheese and jalapenos. I also got some fruit for dessert.

Meat wise, I tried everything that came by our table: bacon wrapped chicken, bacon wrapped filet, pork sausage, parmesan chicken, all cuts of beef, lamb, chicken and pork. My favorite was the cut that's the main pic on their yelp profile. I believe it's the picanha (or sirloin)? It was nice and rare with lots of flavor. The outside had a nice crispness to it which I adored. Most of the huge pieces of beef had rare to medium rare spots in it, but most of their meat was too cooked for me. I like my lamb and beef rare, but most of their meat was medium and up. Especially the lamb which was mostly medium well to well done.

I've only gone to the other SF Brazilian steakhouse on Market a couple times and their other restaurant in San Mateo. I have to say, I prefer that restaurant over this one. They have more of a selection. Both in their salad bar area and in meats.

During dinner, I also got a Black cherry manhattan: knob creek rye, martini & rossi sweet vermouth, luxardo cheery sangue morlacco, orange bitters, black cherry ($15). It was a good drink, but on the pricey side.

Overall, I did get my meat fix, but I was a little disappointed in their selection. Where were the chicken hearts, grilled pineapple, etc? Plus, after I was done eating, I saw a plate of ribs being carried by one of the servers. Only after reading some of the reviews here, did I realized you have to request them. A real bummer as I would have liked to try that dish.

After leaving, I did feel meat wasted. But I couldn't help but think, I would have enjoyed a steak prepared exactly the way I wanted instead of a bunch of random meat that was overcooked (for me). Glad I came by and checked them out, but my experience was just alright.
author: Elena N.

description:
The food was okay, meats mediocre being a hit or miss but nothing special. Some sides were surprisingly good. 

MEATS:
Ranging from juicy and flavorful to dry, tough, tasteless and overdone. Quality was okay.
Pork Tenderloin - 2/5 flavorless, dry and tough
Picanha - 4/5 One of my favorites, the rarer cuts were fatty and tender
Bacon Wrapped Filet - 3/5 Filet is lacking in flavor but that's to be expected. The bacon fat infused into it in some bites. Great texture though, rare inside, juicy and tender
Flank Steak - 3/5 Nice char, on the chewy and dry side
Top Sirloin - 4/5 Probably my favorite cut in terms of flavor, great smokey char, rare inside and juicy. Downside is there was a lot of fat and gristle.
Ribeye - 2/5 Had to ask for this cut, disappointing, overdone and dry
Garlic seasoning was great on some cuts

SIDES:
Cheese bread (pao de queijo) - Like eating buttery cheesy clouds. Cream puff like in structure with a firm outer shell and buttery, cheesy fluffy insides. One of my favorite parts of the meal!
Polenta Fries - Warm and crispy throughout.
Fried Plantains - Soft, sweet, and caramelized, a nice reset for in between meat courses.

SALAD BAR:
Bacon - limpy, cold, weak
Proscuitto - flavorless
Salame - Not bad
Manchego - Standard
Hearts of Palm - great
Beets - tough, too raw
Mozzarella - soft and fresh

DESSERT:
Key Lime Pie - 2/5 Three layers: cold and cardboard graham cracker crust, dense and blandly sweet custard layer, best part was the white whipped cream layer was light and lime-infused. Green syrup drizzled over was particularly offensive and lingered with its artificial made-in-lab aroma.
Chocolate Mousse Cake - 3/5 Mousse layers were okay, cake layers a little bland. The white sauce drizzled on was also terrible and tasted like a vanilla Glade plugin.

AMBIANCE: Had a reservation for 2 and were promptly seated. We were in this weird corner table facing a wall and window but the privacy was nice and servers never forgot about us and came around often. Definitely does not feel like an upscale restaurant. Ambiance is weak, I know it was a former Chevy's but the booth furniture was tacky, the wall I was facing looked unfinished with scratches and leftover hooks still in the wall.

SERVICE: Nice and engaging. The first server poured the soda too quickly and spilled some on the table but was apologetic and it wasn't a big deal. Servers rotated around well, filled my water, and they work as a team. A lot of upselling on other items: drinks, Pellegrino, post dinner Bailey's coffee (you must have a death wish to want to cap it off with even more food and calories at this point).

With some non-alcoholic beverages, the total came out to be around $80 per person pre-tax and tip. If you're into quantity, then it might be worth it but I'd rather have a really nice, pared down steak dinner or picked up a pack from Costco and grilled them myself. The value for price wasn't there, so I wouldn't come again. Redeeming parts were the nice service and variety of meats, if you asked for it.
author: Truc N.

description:
Yay for meat lovers united.

All you can eat hand carved delicious brazilian meats. I'm salivating just thinking about it. I'm a huge fan of Fogo de Chao, have been since I was living in LA.

I took the BF here for his Bday dinner and he was very happy with the selection of meats, the market bar, and the quality of the food.

I believe my favorite cuts were the pichanta? and the top serloin. If you're a lamb fan, they were serving lamb chops as well. They also have some pork ribs and chicken thrown into the mix if you're nota heavy straight beef person, but honestly, it'll be a waste to come and not have them.

of note: there is a man, very lovely man, that goes around trying to sell you a platter of shrimp cocktail.. FYI this is extra!

I would definitely come back for a celebratory meal. They have lots of space and looks like they can accommodate large parties :)
author: Diane T.

description: Love every meat they serve. Ambiance and location is perfect. Will definitely come back when im craving meat.
author: Ryan M.

description:
This was the first time I visited Fogo de Chão and I have to say it was an amazing experience that compares to many other very good restaurants I've visited over the last several months.

For those that want to learn about this place, Fogo de Chão is a Brazilian Steakhouse. It's a little upscale and might be a bit expensive especially if you go through 4 bottles of wine like we did on our visit. :-)

I really don't think the restaurant was over-priced compared to the quality of the place, environment, food and service level that they provide. I am including some of my pictures to this review so you can get a sense of what the place looks like. Despite the restaurant being almost to full capacity, the service was excellent, responsive and everyone would come and help you immediately if you needed anything else. 

The restrooms were crispy clean. Needless to say, the rest of the restaurant was also very clean, neatly arranged and ready for more people to enjoy the experience.

The food was amazing. I tried everything from beef to lamb, chicken and pork. There was nothing I didn't like. The meat was exquisite, soft and juicy. I like my beef medium-rare mostly. Chicken and pork were also really good and cooked to perfection. Unfortunately, I didn't have a chance to try any seafood. I will have to try it on my next visit.

They have several side dishes that compliment the food and I especially liked the garlic mashed potatoes and the fried bananas. 

In regards to wines, they have an extensive menu of very good wines and brands all across the spectrum. If you're into wine and good food, this is probably a great place to visit. 

To finish my review, I want to thank Mahelly Ferreira, Restaurant Manager of the San Francisco restaurant. She came a few times to our table to ask if everything was well and to see if we needed anything else. She was very friendly and made us feel like we were old-time customers or friends. She really took good care of us and she was key in making our afternoon stay at Fogo de Chão a great experience.
author: Rafael O.

description: Honestly loved everything about this place. The beef choices were out of this world!!! Wish I lived closer to SF.
author: Angelina G.

description:
Short: over priced and not up to standards. 
I was here with a group of friends for dinner. I had been to the Fogo in LA and had an enjoyable experience so I was ok with trying this one over House of Prime Rib or Harris. Big mistake. The salad bar was awesome but the meat was a total let down. They came around multiple times with every single different cut of sirloin you can think of. They were good, but I didn't spend $60 pre tax, tip, or whatever else you get to eat the cheapest cut of meat in the restaurant. Their chicken was one of the best items (cognac marinaded) but it was chicken. They only came around with the filet and ribeye after they had stuffed us with the cheaper meets. The service for the most part was good. Only complaint was that my water glass was always empty. Even when the waiter would come to our table I'd have to ask him to refill my water as he walked away. I actually ended up refilling my own water twice. They were also out of chicken hearts, which was the one thing I was really looking forward to. Now onto the bathrooms. It was easily the worst kept bathroom I've ever been in at a formal restaurant. The stalls were filthy to the point I had to go get a paper towel to wipe down the toilet. Both of them were like this. They were also out of toilet paper in both stalls. The trash bin was overfilled with discarded hand towels. It was terrible. I could never imagine this happening at other high end chains like Mastro's, Mortons's, or Ruth's Chris. I can easily say that I will not be coming back here. Any time soon. There are too many good restaurants in the city to justify coming to a place like this.
author: David S.

description: Meat was great and concept was very fun. However, the all you can eat didn't include desert or non-alcohol drink. Feel can be a bit more diverse if you want to offer all you can eat.
author: Anya C.

description:
I hit this place up during Restaurant Week, it was $65 a person.

And I could not keep up. So. Much. Meat. I've never been so full in my life. Thank goodness they had a card on the table to signify keep the meat coming or pause the meat line up. 

Excellent service. When the staff comes over to the tables with the meat options, they ask what type of cut you wanted (i.e., medium, medium rare, well done). The only time my plate was empty of meat was before I started eating and at the end when I was struggling to continue shoving meat in my mouth. Overall the wait staff were really attentive. 

There were quite a few options that you could choose as sides. Essentially you get to select whatever you want from a large table, ranging from rices, salads, cheeses, bread, veggies, fruits, sauces and more.
author: Ashley G.

description:
So we went here on Fat Tuesday (Mardis Gras) because was going to give up meat.  I'm not really impressed as much.

I ilke Espetus and Pampas in Palo Alto so I have that to compare to. 

Espetus and Pampas have a really big salad bar. 

But you are here for the meats and where are the chicken hearts.    So already -1.  The cost too is more then.  So again -1 for the value.    Then there's for some reason the taste of the meat it was more salty then I was used to.  

It was okay.   

On my second time to go there I went to their happy hour and it looked promising but I haven't tried the foods yet.   I'll give it another try when for lunch or for happy hour again.   But their happy hour doesn't look too bad and their bartenders and staff were accommodating to us.  

I work in the same building so I kinda feel bad for the bad review.    But oh well.   I can always change it later.  I have a feeling I'm going to have a lot of changes to decide better but this intro to Fogo de Chao wasn't the best first impression.
author: Homer S.

description: Overrated! Overpriced! Maybe an off-day for them. Though the staffs were all friendly & attentive.
author: Roger R.

description: This was such a fun place to eat! Everything was so good, I wasn't too impressed by the salad bar but it was still good. We went early so there was barely anyone there and they kept the meat coming until we were in food coma. The drinks are nice and strong and the array of desserts is divine. It's a great experience I just couldn't eat enough, it's a place where you need to bring your appetite.
author: Marissa S.

description: Excellent service!!!! Caipirinha 100% recommended, food was top quality, salad bar plenty of food , different choices of meat, highly recommended!!!
author: Cristian O.

description:
3.5 STARS

I despise those "Facebook Memory" reminders (A year ago...3 years ago...). I want to live in the moment! 

That's was until an old NYE post popped up this NYE. It reminded me of the long drunken trek to get home from a NYE party 5 years ago: walking in the rain for over 2 hours...in 5 inch heels like a new born baby giraffe on roller skates...enjoying my first meal of the year next to passed out hobos at Carl Jr. in the Tenderloin at 3 am...getting shoooo'd away by the Four Seasons security staff while trying to hail a cab home (I guess we looked like hookers?)...and finally getting home soaking wet at 5 am. It was like the walk of shame...without the happy ending. 

It was certainly a night to remember BUT never again (I ended up with laryngitis). I'm too old for that sh*t. 

This year, I'm ringing in the New Year with a meat orgy!

As a Fogo de Chão virgin, I kept my expectations low since I'm not a fan of AYCE and buffets. But we choose to dine at Fogo de Chão for NYE because we didn't want to pay for some overpriced NYE prix fix menu. For being open less than 2 weeks in their new San Francisco location, the service was stellar but the churrasco is MUCH better at Espetus.

P R I C E S
Dinner is $59.95 and lunch is $39.95 which includes endless amounts of meat sticks served by strapping gauchos, market table (salad + cured items), and Brazilian sides.  

Cocktails are overpriced at $15-$17 but during Happy Hour (M-F 4:30 pm -6:30 pm), they're $7-$8 at the bar! Get any of the Caipirinhas: http://bit.ly/1R6hAif! 

B E W A R E   O F   U P S E L L I N G
As soon as we were seated, the staff asked, "Would you like a bottle of Panna or Pellegrino sparkling?" Sneaky! I'm not blaming the staff since that's what they're trained to do but I dislike Fogo de Chão's practice of upselling $10 bottled water, $20 shrimp cocktail, and $10 dessert especially at an AYCE place. 

C H A R R U S C O
http://bit.ly/1PH19rq
There's supposedly about 16 meat options but we only saw only 9-10 options. No grilled pineapple (boo!). I later found out via a food blog that the more premium meats like the beef ribs (I really wanted to try this) are by request only. How are customers suppose to know this when you do not inform them AND do not offer a menu of your meat offerings?! Not being upfront/withholding information is borderline deceptive IMO.

+ Ribeye: Fav of the night! Well-marbled and perfectly seasoned, the ribeye was incredibly rich and tender. 
http://bit.ly/1UpA5My
+ Leg of lamb: Tender and nicely gamey.

- Bacon Wrapped Filet Mignon: Terrible!  Salty, hard, and dry. 
- Pork Sausage: Well-seasoned but on the drier side.
- Top sirloin: Tough and sinewy.
- Bottom Sirloin: Tough and chewy.
- Pork Ribs: Dry and flavorless.
- Lamb Chops: Chewy.

I felt sorry for the gaucho who had to serve the Parmesan crusted pork. That meat stick got as much love as a microp*nis. 

S I D E S
http://bit.ly/1OGBrhr & http://bit.ly/1R9Xioq
+ Cheese bread: Warm, fluffy, and cheesy (gluten-free).
+ Polenta fries: Crispy and soft.
- Garlic Mash: Yucky, pasty texture.

S A U C E S
+ Chimichurri: Herbaceous but needed more acid.
- Horseradish: Zero kick.

M A R K E T   T A B L E
http://bit.ly/1OEakn7
+ Brown Sugar & Pepper Bacon: Crunchy, sweet & spicy porky deliciousness.
+ Marinated mushrooms: Tender and good amount of acid.
+ Pickled veggies: Helped cut through the richness of the meats.
+ Fresh veggies: Crisp.
+ Oranges, grapefruit: Super juicy.

- Feijoada: Like something out of the Great Depression era--bland, watery, and meatless. 
- Smoked Salmon: Hella salty!
- Charcuterie: Hella salty!

D E S S E R T (+$10-$11)
*Carmelized Pineapple w/ vanilla ice cream ($10): Juicy, sweet, and refreshingly tart. Sprinkle the brown sugar & pepper bacon on top of the ice cream for a crunchy porky sweet heat! 
http://bit.ly/1OEaStc

S E R V I C E
Young and eager to please, the staff was very enthusiastic and attentive (they were very well trained by the seasoned staff). The staff is 95% men...handsome at that. Cougars would go nuts in this place especially with the gauchos (Caio was the best) eager to serve you their meat stick with a warm smile! 

A M B I A N C E
Upscale, classy, and a large open space but the corner booths in the front were cramped compared to the spaciousness in the back of the dining room. Great for large groups! 

P A R K I N G
No valet. Yerba buena garage is 2 blocks away on 4th/Mission.

Fogo de Chão exceeded my low expectations with the stellar service but with the $100 pp tab (including 1 drink, tax & tip), the meat quality was more of a miss. I prefer spending that $100+ at a fancy steakhouse like Alexander's, Hillstone, or Bobo's where I know all the cuts will be top-notch and cooked perfectly. I know they're still very new but I'm rounding down my rating because of Fogo de Chão's upselling tactics and not offering their full meat selection upfront. I REALLY wanted to try those thick, girthy beef ribs. *Sad pouty lip*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Tried the one on Santana Row and the food and service was horrible. 

Decided to try this location and food was horrible. 

For the amount of money they're charging - spring a little bit more and just go to espetus.
author: Bebe P.

description:
After discovering that a new Fogo de Chao was opening in San Francisco, I immediately set out to make reservations for my boyfriend and I. My boyfriend and I are not new to Brazilian steakhouses, so we were excited to see what Fogo de Chao has to offer. We arrived promptly to our dinner reservations and were seated immediately. The place is huge and we were seated in the far corner at the end of the restaurant. With our distant seating, I was hoping we wouldn't be excluded for the rounds of meats swarming around the restaurant. Our waitress asked if we wanted anything to drink within just a few seconds of taking our seats. Similar to other reviews, there was a bit of up selling, but not a considerable amount that effected our dining room experience. Please be aware that the prices for drinks are ridiculous and there are no free refills on drinks or soda. 

I was surprised to see that even in the far back corner of the restaurant of where we were seated, we received an immense amount of attention. The service was good and each carver was kind of enough to ask if we wanted a second piece - they were definitely not stingy or gave judging stares to my hungry-looking eyes! I was also impressed with the service from our waitress because she made her rounds to our table to make sure everything was ok. I thoroughly enjoyed that she asked if we would like to replace our plates with new ones, which I haven't experienced much at other Brazilian steakhouses. I also didn't have to wave down our waitress on ordering more side dishes because we were immediately asked if we wanted more.  The meats were delicious and I love that they offered a basket full of cheese breads! 

Unfortunately, I was a bit disappointed in the market bar. The market bar did not have a great selection of hot plates and mostly served fruits and cold grilled veggies. I only went up to the market bar maybe once or twice, but a lot of the items were not refilled. I get that the big money maker is in the meat, but with the price you're paying, I expect more at the market bar than fruit. I was also sad to find out that they do not serve grilled pineapples!!!! The grilled pineapples served at Brazilian steakhouses are usually the highlight of a perfect meal for me. The restaurant also serves the included sides of mashed potatoes, fried plantains and polenta, but honestly, doesn't have much flavor/season to them. 

Honestly, with the amount I paid for dinner, I would much rather venture out to another Brazilian steakhouse for a similar or even lower pricing than here. It was a good experience, though.
author: Victoria K.

description: Amazing selection of meats and the buffet style sides and salads are to die for! Customer service was good and the manager even came to our table to make sure we were happy with our service and selections. We visited this location because we were in San Francisco for the weekend but we'll definitely be visiting the LA locations frequently.
author: Kristina D.

description:
Came here for lunch on a weekday with a friend and was surprised to find how busy it was even on a Monday at 1PM; there was a bit of a line too, which wasn't terrible just surprising. Would recommend getting a reservation to skip the line. 

It was my first time there and while it was a little intimidating, the servers were very nice and explained the service to us. The service itself was very attentive and were able to answer all of our questions. I had a promotional gift card for 2 meals that I don't think covered the Market and alcoholic drinks, but when I asked for the bill I found that both were not charged to my bill! That was a very nice surprise and much appreciated--the staff is extremely accommodating and just exceptional. 

As regards to the food, the Market displays were very fresh and a lot of variety. The meats themselves were very delicious and it was lovely to have them freshly carved at the table. It was just a little difficult to keep up with all the different varieties floating around. If you don't eat fast enough the meat will cool, and the blood and fats will coagulate taking away from the higher quality of meat you're supposed to be eating. So I guess my advice would be to not have more than 3 kids of meat on your plate at once so you can enjoy them at peak freshness. The mashed potatoes, fried bananas, and cheese buns were perfection, too!
author: Alison M.

description:
I was lucky to have my friend Heather pay for my birthday meal here.  Usually when you go to a place like Fogo, you have to have a plan.  What do you eat?  What do you not eat?  What is in that gray area where you can go either way?  Alcohol or no alcohol?  These are just a few questions on what every diner at Fogo has to answer during their time here.

Unfortunately, I did not have those questions in mind when I came here.  I pretty much sat down, ordered a drink, went to salad bar and avoided all carbs as much as possible, and then waited for the meat to come.  Friendly warning, the salad bar is no joke.  There is a lot of good stuff there and it's very tempting to get one of "everything" but that will lead you to disaster and take up precious stomach space for the meat bonanza.  I highly recommend filling only half of your plate.

When the meat comes, I usually go for things like filet, ribeye, lamb, and other more elaborate preparations or high quality meat.  Fogo has a thing about doing sirloin and preparing it different ways.  For me, I certainly wasn't going to waste space on sirloin but again, you may feel differently.  When the meat is sitting there on a skewer in front of your face, your first instinct is to just say "yes" and ask for a piece.  Then another person comes by and does the same thing and another person...and another person...the endless cycle continues until you flip your circular button to the colored red side.

Also don't forget about the cheese bread, mashed potatoes, the yuca, and the fried plantains at the table.  They will also refill that for you as well so be mindful of your stomach capacity.

Service of course was great although at some point, food coma set in after the first hour or so in combination with the alcohol and large amounts of meat.  I do remember that our server checked in on us many times and the manager even paid a visit to our table.  This place is truly first rate in terms of how proper service functions.  

This place is definitely a special occasion sort of place.  I almost wish that I had more special occasions just to come here more often.  As for whether they are on par or better than competitors like Espetus, that's up to you to decide.
author: Ben H L.

description:
I went here a few months ago for a friend's birthday. I had never been to a steakhouse like this so it was a really cool experience. I got the meat and the salad bar thing. There was a nice selection of salads and fruit and vegetables. There was also a soup, a type of chili. It was running low when I wanted to try some so I didn't get a chance to try it.

They give you a two-sided card to use when you want to request or deny different meats. The servers would come around with their different trays of meats to carve for you. I tried just about everything and they were all delicious and very juicy. 

I'm definitely looking forward to going again and trying the things I missed.  Valet parking was $20.
author: Jeremi W.

description: The food was amazing and what made the experience even better was the excellent service that Tri provided. I highly recommend this place and I'll definitely be back soon!
author: MaryAnn P.

description:
3.5 stars

My family decided to dine here recently.  While we have been to other churrascarias, this was our first time at Fogo de Chao in the Bay Area.  Our group consisted of 5 adults and three children (1/2 price for children, free for those under 7).

I started with a Mange Refresco, made with vodka, basil and mango puree.  Delicious, refreshing and not too sweet.

A trip to the Market Table led me to a variety of salads, vegetables, candied bacon,fruit,  cheeses and cured meats  While its tempting to fill up, I had to save room for the beef, chicken, pork and lamb.  Each table is also offered cheesy bread rolls, caramelized bananas, polenta fries, mashed potatoes and feijoada, the traditional black bean stew.  One must be selective and strategic in order to enjoy everything.

Some meats are better than others so it's good to be picky.  I found the pork loin, chicken breast and drummettes to be on the dry side but enjoyed the sausage, pork ribs and some cuts of steak (some where juicy and very tender, some where dry and a bit tough).   Don't forget to ask for their sauces.  The Chimichurri is a favorite of mine and helps cut through the richness of the meat. 

Service was great.  Our waiter was so friendly and contributed to us all having a great time.  

This space is great for meat lovers and great for large groups.  They were very accommodating to the kids.   Come with a lot of room in your belly.

Parking is available at nearby garages or on the street.
author: Melissa L.

description: The brunch was fantastic! The staff made sure you got meat cooked to your preference. Awesome variety. The hash was delicious. Great for small and large groups. This is now a new favorite of my family.
author: Kelly J.

description:
A GREAT DINING EXPERIENCE.  At the outset, let me state that I am not really a steakhouse kinda guy (whether Brazilian or au naturel), but the service and the food are amazing at this place!

Tender, deliciously-seasoned beef, chicken, and lamb (plus the occasional shrimp) come marching by your table, ready for the picking, at very regular intervals.  The salad bar is HUGE, and has a vast selection of fruits, vegetables, salami, chorizo, and God knows what else----too much to list.  The wine list is also HUGE and OVERWHELMING.  The staff is uniformly warm and friendly and attentive.  A SPECIAL SHOUT-OUT TO STEWART (or is it STUART?), the smiling manager, who walked around the restaurant checking on all of the customers, and charming them with his smooth southern style. Prepare to be dazzled!

ONE MAJOR CAVEAT:  IT'S EXPENSIVE.  Don't expect to get out of here without spending major bucks. But for a fun and delicious dining experience, it's worth a splurge.
author: Samuel B.

description: The food, including the roaming servers and the buffet, is great and keeps us coming back but the waiters are HORRIBLE with bringing beverages, refills, the check etc. we waited at least 20 minutes for drinks, at least 20 minutes for the bill, at least another 15 to have the bill brought back to sign... just so so bad... but if you're not in a hurry or drinking any liquids, go ahead.
author: Greta W.

description: Absolutely AMAZING!!!! Staff is amazing and the food is to die for! I can't wait to go back!!
author: Mary W.

description: Been here 3x now and I would rate their food as the best in the City... 5 Stars overall for taste n service.
author: Tone D.

description:
This is without a doubt the worst experience I've ever had with a Brazilian steakhouse, and I've been to several different ones of them many times over the years. Across the board, my family and I were disappointed by just about everything. The list below is a direct comparison of the problems we had here compared to other similar restaurants, which don't have these issues.

1. The meat is blandly seasoned. Almost every meat had little flavor, and some actually had bad flavor.

2. The meat is on average served too rare. At every other place we've been to like this, the meat tends to be medium, which satisfies a broader range of people. Many customers don't like meat that's barely cooked.

3. The meat is overly fatty and just plain gross. We wasted a ton of meat. Again, we haven't had this problem with any other Brazilian steakhouse.

4. There's a weak variety of meat. We didn't feel like there was enough different items going around.

5. The meat comes around in a totally uneven way--feast or famine. They really couldn't get the pacing down right, and it was neither overly busy or overly slow during our visit. We either had too much meat coming too fast, or else 5 to 10 minutes was going by with nothing happening.

6. The salad bar area had the worst and weakest selection we've ever experienced. The four people in my family barely picked anything from it to eat, and at other places we fill our plates.

7. The salad bar area kept running out of key items we wanted to have from it (i.e., the few we were actually interested in).

8. Perhaps most bizarrely of all, soda isn't served from a fountain. It's served from expensive, single-serving, non-refillable glass bottles. As if that's bad enough, they're only 8 ounces--not even the size of a 12-ounce can. I don't think I've ever encountered another restaurant in my life like this. It's easy to drop $20 just on soda for four people and still not have enough.

9. A staple of every Brazilian steakhouse is grilled pineapple. All they had here was cold pineapple, which was severely disappointing given that this is usually a highlight of such a trip.

10. Getting our bill was difficult at the end of the meal and took too long. Then there was also a (minor) mistake on it.

11. Last, but not least, this place is way overpriced. We paid about $140 (without tip) for two adults and two kids, which is a joke for the lack of value received.

To summarize, for the first time ever, everyone in my family left a Brazilian steakhouse still hungry and totally disappointed. And that's a pitiful shame because that just doesn't happen elsewhere. We will never go back to this restaurant again.
author: Jackson S.

description:
First off, I love the ambiance it's warm, romantic and inviting. Our group was a bit large for lunch, nonetheless the service was excellent. I tried the salad bar, which my taste buds loved, and got full. Then I attempted to taste the garlic steak, I will say I was slightly disappointed since it only had a hint of the flavor, then I tried the sirloin wrapped in bacon, it was good, tried the chicken drumstick, it was okay, the sirloin steak was also good but at this point I was already full and couldn't enjoy eating anymore food. If I go again, I'll skip the meat and just do the Salad Bar.  

For the rest of you meat-loving carnivores, skip the salad an feast on the 8-9 different types of meat.
author: Petra M.

description:
I mean yes the meat was delicious but oh my goodness the bill ended up seeming nuts based on the overall experience. 4 people, 1 cheaper bottle of wine from the list, 2 desserts and one $500 bill. Phew.

While the side dishes weren't bad, I think there could definitely be more variety in heat. The only warm side dishes are rice and beans and the polenta fries and bread they provide. Some of the vegetables could use a little dolling up too (the broccoli was just raw broccoli). 

On meat and service alone this place would be 5 stars, but factoring in the price and sides it's a 3 for me.
author: Anna M.

description:
I dined at the SF location with my family (8 of us) for the first time and was thoroughly disappointed in the food and service. 

The "market table" resembled a low budget salad bar with very slim pickings. The bowl labled "spinach" had no spinach in it, but a mixed green salad. There were 3 different types of quinoa salads, all flavorless. Looking at the website, it said the market table was extensive, but it was sad. There also were no soup options like the website stated.

For the sides, a friend mentioned the rice and beans were good, however none of that was brought out to our table either. We got some mashed potatoes and polenta/bananas nothing else was mentioned to us or offered. According to your website, there are about 3 other side dishes that should have come out with our meal.

Service: when we sat down, I advised I wanted regular water so the waiter took my glass and NEVER brought me back any water. It was also extremely hard to get the attention of someone to get help. The waiter was not attentive and did not ensure our dining experience was flawless. 

My main concern is that for $62/pp my expectation was to have the full experience and to have everything that should have been included offered. For a $600 prior to tip bill, this is unacceptable.
author: N B.

description:
Service is SUPERB here.

Came here with my fiance to just try out their food since we have heard so many things- but they were fully booked and it was a half hour or more to get a seat so we opted for the bar after hearing they serve food there.

We sat down at the table next to the grill that is enclosed with glass so you can see the servers go in and out and slicing beautiful, jaw-dropping gorgeous pieces of prime beef, chicken, what-have-you. That was a bad choice since we both regretted not getting the buffet haha.

We got a beer ($10) and the beef sliders as well as the beef kebab/on the stick.

The meat for the sliders was HORRENDOUSLY disgusting- it was full of fat and gristle (the hard tendinous part that nobody can chew, nevertheless swallow)- the meat itself was barely 1/3 of what was in the slider itself. I just ate the buns (they are the Brazilian style cheesy bread and SO good).

The kebab was really tasty- nothing wrong with it at all. This was $15 for the kebab and the sliders were $10.

However, where they redeemed themselves is the bartender/server who came over and when I mentioned this casually, since I was not trying to get comped or anything, just letting him know the quality was definitely mediocre and the meat was not up to Fogo standards as I know it- he went and took the more expensive kebab off our bill! Without any prompt. It was superb customer service and totally appreciated since we literally just ate the buns off the sliders and didn't even touch the meat since you could barely eat it- or just chew it like bubble-gum and spit it out.

So- will be coming back to give their full on "buffet" experience a try out ($65 per person...) and will have to fast for a week before going here to load up on the different meats available.

Thanks to that bartender / server / waiter! That was really nice.
author: David T.

description: The salad bar was really excellent. The meat was OK it all started tasting the same after a bit. I would expect each meat to have its own unique flavor, marinade or seasoning but it didnt. The service was good. It was super expensive so for me the value was not there because the meat wasn't exceptional.
author: Erin M.

description: I enjoyed a lovely evening dining with family here recently. Like Samuel, I am not a big meat eater but truly enjoyed the high quality beef, chicken, pork and lamb. The gauchos brought it to us hot from the grill at whatever gradation of doneness we desired.  The salad bar is extensive with tasty cheeses, thin sliced meats and bacon. The service was excellent and staff super attentive and motivated to keep us happy and satisfied. I enjoyed the ambience immensely as I do not get to cross the bridge for dinner very often. Choose the cheesecake for desert.
author: Susangela M.

description: The service is amazing however the selection was limited on meats. There are menu items that I am used to being included in the service but wasn't.
author: Valencia K.

description:
Fogo de Chao Brazilian Steakhouse has finally arrived in San Francisco near the Moscone Convention Center in the old Chevys Fresh Mex Restaurant that was in that location on the corner of Howard and 3rd Street and I am so glad I finally got a chance to sample this high-end authentic Brazilian Churrasco where they the meats are cooked over live fire and served on a skewer, while being cut on your plate ready to eat! Fogo de Chão is actually pronounced "fo-go dee shown" not "fo-go dee chow," like I know all of you thought it was, and the name refers to the traditional gaucho style of cooking in which large cuts of meat were roasted in a pit in the ground.

Thankfully there was no fire pit here, just succulent slices of meat from all of the juiciest parts of the cow, as well as pork, chicken and sausages. I had been wanting to try this place ever since they opened late last year and so did many of my Yelp Elite friends like Hazel, Michael and Christine. Two members of our party were celebrating their birthdays and wisely joined their eClub where they were each given 25 dollar coupons. I joined the eClub and got a 15 dollar coupon just for signing up. It was great way to save money because we knew Fogo was not cheap with dinners being 59.95 a person. We also saved money but bringing our own wine bottle as the corkage fee was a decent 35 dollars a bottle. 

There was plenty to eat at Fogo, starting with the Market Table, which provides a bounty of salads and fresh fruits and vegetables, not to mentions cheeses, charcuteries and smoked salmon. And then there was also the Feijoada bar, which serves the traditional black bean stew from Brazil, along with white rice. But our dining group knew not to get anywhere near those tantalizing treats because they want you to fill up and therefore less of that expensively grilled meat. Once we were sat our server Alfredo knew what we were all about, he uncorked our wine, as we perused the cocktail menu, and then we told him bring on the meat! But first I had smartly done some research before we arrived and it was my fellow Yelpers and not the menu that told me about the complimentary Brazilian side dishes like mashed potatoes, crispy polenta, and plantains. I was also sure we got plenty of meat dipping sauces like the Chimichurri, Horseradish sauce, and mint jelly. Not to mention a basket full of the Pao De Queijo which were warm, soft cheesy bread rolls are served throughout the entire meal. 

But we could eat, were quickly interrupted by Stuart who was there to push, what else? An additional add on this time shrimp served raw cocktail style or cooked. We wisely passed because we knew we were in for a meat extravaganza! To attract meat-laden chefs, diners use a card that is red on one side and green on the other: red means do not approach, while green means bring on the meat sweats. Let's just say there was plenty of green at our table. We ate smartly, we knew we had all night to feast on all 18 varieties of meat that was served at Fogo so we took our time, enjoyed our wine to go with meat and waited for the sweats to arrive.

The signature dish at Fogo is actually picanha, the prime part of the top sirloin, though filet mignon follows close behind. We also all loved the New York Steak and the rib eye. Everything was cooked just to our liking, medium rare to medium well, everyone had a choice.  There's a helpful list that they place at each table to describe what parts of the cattle you are eating. One caveat is that there is in fact a lot of sodium in their meats so make sure you get plenty of water to drink while you're there. There's also a healthy selection of bacon-wrapped goods for those who are really jonesing for some meat sweats but the only bad part of those meats were that they tend to cook faster with all of the bacon around it and therefore they left the meat drier (more Chimichurri sauce right?). A lot of the pork, lamb, chicken and sausage cuts were also dried out, despite the addition of jelly, so my advice is if you like a steak then stick to it, and ask for it again. They will bring anything to your table if you ask for it. And we did and our other server Amanda made sure we got it!

Fogo is a once in a lifetime special occasion meal that the whole family will love. At almost sixty dollars a person the place doesn't come cheap. There's a reason this place is so centrally located in the mid-town area of the city with the convention center and museums literally across the street. The best time is to come for your birthday month, if you join the eClub they will give you plenty of coupons to make sure you come back for more. Plus they were nice enough to give us two complimentary desserts for said birthdays. They tasted super sweet and clearly weren't their signature dishes at Fogo which is fine because we all got plenty of meat to go around and savor until each of us returns again to enjoy this bounty of food with a Brazilian flair.
author: Jason F.

description: Had a great date night for valentines we made reservations and they were really quick getting us in there was even people who didn't have reservations and the wait was very quick the waiters And servers were very quick and attentive our drinks were never empty had loads of amazing cutts of meat
author: Kaylee T.

description: Fogo Market is a self-serve express lunch spot that is located inside the same entrance as the Starbucks at this location, and is not accessible from inside Fogo de Chao, the parent restaurant. I picked up a hearty and flavorful Brazilian chicken & black bean stew (feijoada) and a large salad picked from a bar of appealing fresh items for just $11. The quality was excellent! I'll definitely be back.
author: Chris T.

description:
Spontaneous decision to try this place out with my BF & 2 friends. We came here on a Monday having high expectations since we've been to other Brazilian steakhouses. We waited about 15 minutes since we did a walk in with no reservation. The ambience was beautiful. I love dim light dinners! 

Our waiter was great he explained to us how Brazilian steak houses work (green keep the meat coming, red I'm either resting or I'm full). There is an appetizer area of the restaurant, I gladly enjoyed prosciutto, salmon loc, mozerella cheese, mushrooms, asparagus. CHEESE BREAD (little balls) are sooooo dangerous but amazing!!! 

Several meats came out and my favorite had to be the top sirloin steak. Love how the servers would coke around carve the meat in front of you and you would either grab it with your tong or they would place it on your plate for you. Usually I'd have rice with my meat but this time I wanted to just have all meat and enjoy as much as I can!

For our drinks we always had a glass of water, I had the famous Brazilian cocktail, my bf got me to get their moscato which was really sweet but in a good way!

For dessert we got the papaya cream. If you've eaten flinestones pushpops growing up... they have similar tastes and it brought me back to my childhood! 

Out of the many Brazilian steak houses that I've tried this is too 3 mainly because I love how their meat is cooked and seasoned in comparison to other places. Will definitely be back here! Maybe my birthday dinner will be here!
author: Melissa Nicole N.

description:
My second time here with my girlfriends and I can say that they have the best drinks. The caipirinha with mango and habanero spice was definitely are favorite one. 
The salad bar is good but nothing special. I was expecting more options of food and sides since that is how it goes in a Brazilian restaurants. Usually with lots of options and typical authentic Brazilian food. I was also very disappointed with the desert menu which don't have any Brazilian authentic desserts. Very Americanized restaurant didn't feel like a Brazilian steakhouse at all.
author: Juliana H.

description: This is probably one of my favorite steak houses that I've been to. The only complaint I would have about Fogo would be the waiters, not the men serving the meat but the actual waiters themselves. I ordered a drink and waited 15 mins for it, we asked for the check and waited 15 mins for it. 15 mins seems like a trend when asking for something from a waiter at Fogo. Other than that I would totally recommend the food to anyone!
author: Anne Marie A.

description:
The basket of cheesy bread balls started dinner on a good note--they were really enjoyable. It was my first time at a Brazilian steakhouse, so I can't make any comparisons. However, the food was mediocre at best. The meat was bland, the salad/sidedish bar was ok, and the best part of the experience was either the bread balls or the chocolate lava cake. 

To add on to the disappointment, the bill came up differently on my credit card statement. Rather than the number I'd written (which lies between the 18% and 20%), they'd charged me for the full 20%. I have a habit of truncating my numbers for easy end-of-the-month calculations, so this immediately caught my eye. It's not a large difference, but it strikes me as dishonest. I'd like to pay the price I intended, whether or not it aligns with one of the numbers suggested "for my convenience". 

So yeah. Food wasn't too bad, but not good enough for me to go there a second time, what with the bill incident.
author: Bao Shan L.

description:
Meat galore. Good service and nice ambience.

Their chef came by my workplace and offered a neat offer for a meal. Took abit of planning to ensure we are all ready for a carnivorous dinner.

Made a reservation via Opentable which offered an additional 100pts for reserving a table which is awesome.

The staff promptly sat us down and was immediately attended by a server. The service was really quite awesome and thoughtful, except perhaps if some of the staff followed through what they said they were going to do. Eg They took my plate and said they wanted to replace with a clean one, which is nice except they never did. I had to request for one. They said they were going to get me this particular meat cos I said I really liked it, they never did. Again I had to ask again for the meat. 

It's an interesting experience where they provide a coaster with one side color green and another red. Green signify "GIVE ME MEAT" while red means "let me finish the food on my place first". It was hilarious and amusing at the same time, the speed of how fast the meat came once we switch it to green, I literally saw a server "ran" to served us those awesome meat!

They have a market table which offer salad, fruits and some light bites. Another table with rice, fruit and soup. Did not try them as I was saving my stomach for the MEAT!

The food itself was pretty good. My favorite is Picanha! I wouldn't called it's awesome though. $59.95 per pax for dinner is rather pricey. 

We ordered creme brûlée for dessert. The portion was huge and tasted pretty good. 

Overall, I would recommend this place for meat lovers and people who enjoy unlimited meat! Make sure you go on an empty stomach.
author: Cindee T.

description:
Fogo de chao was a fun experience. I took my family here for my nephews bday and it did not disappoint. The service was fantastic, with the waiter checking on us multiple times. The people that served the meats were also friendly.

The meal itself was fantastic. There is an open salad bar that allows you to pick up veggies, fruits and even smoked salmon. The highlight of the meal were the meats. Their various beef cuts was fantastic. It had a tasty beef flavor and was super juicy. Other meats like the lamb were also quite tasty.

Overall this was a great experience. I would definitely go again.
author: Keith L.

description: Amazing dinner experience! Not only was the food amazing, the customer service of ALL employees was second to none. From the hostess receiving and seating our party of 5 reservation, to each meat carver, the bar tender, and our designated host, all we're on point the evening of Saturday, May 13th. We were in the city for my brother's bachelor party and I was happy that his first experience at Fogo was a memorable one. I especially want to thank the young Asian lady who's name I fail to recall, that cleared our table prior to offering us the dessert menu. She was very personable and took time to ask us about our plans for the remainder of the evening, even giving us suggestions of bars in the area. I have no doubt she was instrumental in management offering us a special complimentary dessert  that was fitting for the occasion... "Game Over!"... lol. Thanks again!
author: Phillip P.

description: Meat sweats. Meat hangover. All of the above are possible after dinner at Fogo de Chao. I recently attended a work meeting/dinner at Fogo de Chao and found myself (happily) overwhelmed by the sheer amount of food and meat! As part of our dinner, we had access to the market table, which boasts various dishes, including: salads, smoked salmon, feijoada, soup (butternut squash), charcuterie (cured meats, aged cheese, and accompaniments), antipasti (artichokes, olives, peppers, mushrooms, mozzarella, roasted garlic, roasted zucchini, sundried tomatoes), roasted beets, hearts of palm, cucumbers, asparagus, green beans, watermelon, pineapple, etc. When we finally settled down at our table, that's when the parade of meat began. You're given a token - one side is green/yes please and the other side is red/no thank you, indicating whether or not you want more meat or not. I'll be honest - my token spent the majority of the evening with green/yes please side up! Meats were brought table side on swords and were hand carved by our waiters. Meats included: steak (picanha, filet mignon, rib eye, sirloin, bacon wrapped steak, beef ribs), chicken, lamb, and pork (pork ribs, pork loin, linguine). We also had various side dishes, including garlic mashed potatoes, cartelized bananas, pay de queijo (warm soft cheesy bread rolls!), and polenta! We also had delicious desserts - don't know how we even had room for dessert - turtle cheesecake, key lime pie, chocolate mousse cake! The food was delicious - definitely wish I had room to eat more! The service was fantastic. Definitely will be back the next time I'm craving MEAT!
author: Irene L.

description: If you like meat, come here. Staff on point. Service is great. It's not everyday eating for me but nice for special occasions. Sorry to say the food gave me the runs.
author: Jawid H.

description: Enjoy visiting the location in LA - food and service is superb. Disappointed that I called and made a reservation only to be told that they did not have my reservation. The hostess in an unprofessional manner told my wife and I that 'she had us and shouldn't be longer than 5-10 mins.' Four parties were seated in front of us and when there was no one in the lobby, we were seated. There was a squabble that was happening with two of our waiters - over who was mainly serving us. Overall, very poor experience from a typically awesome restaurant.
author: Shan C.

description: Really cool dining experience. Come with an appetite for meat and a wallet. Seating and service are fine
author: Shannon D.

description: One of my favorite places to go for Brazilian food. Friendly staff, delicious food, fast service and most of all amazing cocktails.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Mmmm mmmm mmmmm!!!
Came here for dinner with hubby last night and boy!!! Sooo delicious!! 
Staff was nice, and even though it was busy we appreciated that they took the time to talk to us! One of the guys, Henry, who was serving the meat, was so super nice and funny!! It's people like that that makes someone want to keep coming back. It doesn't take much, but it makes a huge difference for the over all experience. 
Food was on point, the steak rib was by far my favorite! The cheese and fig jam was delicious too.
Would've been 5 stars, but the sides were not that good, a taste less mashed potatoes, and some grilled bananas or what the heck it was that looks really unappetizing. The drinks were over priced as well.
Anyways, I'll be back!!
author: Sandra L.

description:
The meats were fantastic, flavorful , tender and cooked to perfection.  Salad bar was also delightful.  For food it was a 4 Star.

Service was terrible.  It stared with being seated 40 minutes after our reservation time.  Once we were seated it took the waiter another 10 min to greet us then after delivering drinks he didn't show up until we were almost done to see how we were doing.  At this point a second glass of wine did make sense.  Water glasses were empty most of the night as we had to stop other staff to get them filled.  At the end the waiter asked if we wanted to se a desert menu and my co-worker said yes.  The waiter disappeared another 25 minutes then on return asked if we would like anything else.
